degree.name: Master of Library and Information Studies
Master of Arts in English
degree.thesis: Winnifred Eaton Reeve’s His Royal Nibs: A Critical Digital Edition

list.item: Supported and collaborated with 20+ DH projects through consultation, back-end, and front-end development

Led sustainable infrastructural developments through the adoption of existing static site generators (e.g. 11ty, Jekyll, Collection Builder), the creation of custom static build pipelines in a variety of programming languages (e.g. XSLT, JavaScript, Python), and the adoption of containerized server infrastructure (Docker)
Created in-depth technical and user-focused documentation to record project practices and approaches
Created and taught workshops on DH tools, platforms, methods, and research approaches, including TEI, XML technologies, Omeka, digital textual editing, and minimal computing
Developed graduate Digital Fellow role in Digital Textual Editing and acted as primary supervisor to two graduate students (Dec. 2022–Aug. 2023; Jan. 2025–Sept. 2025)
Mentored and trained undergraduate and graduate students within project teams in DH methods (including TEI encoding, Git and GitHub, XPath, and web development fundamentals)
Partnered with and advised on institutional and national grant applications with faculty and external partners
Engaged in Library-wide and divisional strategic planning, including revising processes and management models for project intake and development within the DHIL
Worked across multiple project teams to develop custom TEI-based digital editions across literary studies, book history, linguistics, transnational history, and the geohumanities
With the Endings Project team, created and developed mechanisms to support the Endings Principles for Digital Sustainability, including the development of staticSearch
Trained undergraduate and graduate students in TEI encoding practices, XML, XPath, XQuery, and XSLT
Developed project infrastructure, TEI schema, and static website development for large-scale digital edition of over 2000+ manuscript pages
Managed project-specific workflows for large-scale transcription campaigns using HTR platforms (such as Transkribus) and associated APIs
Created custom mapping of TEI encoded texts to IIIF and built a custom IIIF viewer in OpenLayers
Researched archival standards to recommend new practices for representing embedded objects within manuscripts in TEI XML
Created custom static map (using OpenLayers, turf.js, and vite) that queries the Open Journal Systems (OJS) API to retrieve geographic information from the Fragmenting the West Coast poetry journal

Developed the technical infrastructure, trained all team members, and guided the digital methods employed by the project to create the first complete archive of the first Asian North American novelist
Oversaw the encoding of over 309 texts and storage of 240 facsimiles and created over 18,000 lines of XSLT transformation for the generation of a fully-archivable and sustainable digital edition
Researched bibliographic standards and created encoding models for encoding early twentieth-century screenplays
Translated knowledge and expertise to ensure communication across multiple teams for creating the Crossing Fonds archive
Serving as a co-editor for special issue of Digital Humanities Quarterly and as co-author on forthcoming article for the special issue
Developed tools and workflows, including widely-cited Endings Principles, for producing archivable, static projects from long-running projects

Connected six distinct datasets in collaboration with Landscapes of Injustice research clusters (including the Nikkei National Museum) to build and develop a comprehensive archive (over 40,000 documents) of historical documents related to the dispossession of Japanese Canadians, including an index of over 27,000 Japanese Canadians.
Developing and maintaining an open-source search engine geared toward static site development in the digital humanities, which has been used by over a dozen projects internationally
Remediated critical editions in custom markup languages to TEI-XML and developed the base schema and technical infrastructure for the LEMDO anthology platform.
Advising Principal Investigator in best practices for development of digital platform
Collaborating with other programmers, web developers, and designers to develop front-end platform
Mentored Junior Programmer in markup languages (TEI) and front-end web development technologies (HTML, CSS, XSLT, and JavaScript)

project.project_name: The Map of Early Modern London

list.item: Researching and writing original encyclopedia entries for early modern place names
Developed novel mechanisms for encoding and processing variant calendar systems in use in early modern London and maintained project document and schema.
Trained and mentored encoders in best practices for encoding early print documents and born-digital texts

project.desc: I worked as the main programmer for this project and helped with creating customized TEI-XML schemas and setting up the XML repository for the project.

At The Internet Shakespeare Editions, I helped in testing and writing conversions from a custom markup language to TEI-XML. I also developed workflow packages and tools to help in expedite scholarly encoding practices.
